reviewText:
So I posted a thread asking whether Takedown: Red Sabre  was any good because I was hoping it would scratch my itch for a slow paced old-school Rainbow 6 shooter. Everyone said that it was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and a huge disappointment and that it was a waste of even the $1 that it's worth even now on Steam.

However, there was one guy who posted a screenshot of his playtime in the game (about 26 hours iirc) and said that everyone itt was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and that it was actually fun. This guy singlehandedly convinced me to buy it anyway and ignore the circlejerk.

I'm very glad that I did.

During my first 3 hours of gameplay I decided to write a list of +s and -s about the game, coming at it from a low-expectation and is-this-game-like-rainbow-6 perspective.

spoiler alert: it was exactly what i hoped it would be

The following is my list of +s and -s about Takedown: Red Sabre based on my experiences with the game. I am a very old school Rainbow 6 player and I came into this game with very low expectations due to the Total Biscuit review (and later PSA), random internet people's advice and opinions about the game.

One thing I want to be clear about here, though, is that I am not the kind of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ who gives a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ about cosmetic â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ like sexy reload animations, graphics, et cetera. Imo all of these things are completely fine. They're not as good as ArmA 3 or Skyrim but they don't take away from my experience at all.

---

While checking this game out and making this list, I fully was wearing my Rainbow 6, Rogue Spear, SWAT 4, and Raven Shield hats and I try to make direct comparisons to each of those games as often as I can in this list for you:

(these are in the order I wrote them down while playing the game)

+ Level editor (not even Tribes has this) is exactly like the old Raven Shield one (because they're based on the same engine), which is way â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing better than the old Rogue Spear one. This is a huge plus for me because I love making custom â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in games and then playing them with my friends.

+ 3 game modes across 13 different maps by default (however the Mission game mode limits the pool to only 5)

+ Mirrors and glass in general actually â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing works -- there are genuine reflections that you can use to see people around corners, such as when on the top floor of the Biolab where you can see enemies under your feet by looking at the tall windows.

+ Gimping works just like in the old Rainbow 6 games.

+ AI is just as good at shooting as you are (assuming that you don't suck at crosshair placement and aiming), but only when they're alerted to your presence. It's exactly like Rainbow 6, except instead of multiple difficulty settings (Recruit, Veteran, Elite) each AI has its own difficulty settings. Some are â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and cowardly whereas others are 360 noscope mlg xxx tier. Either extreme is very rare (maybe 1 per mission) and most AI are probably in between Raven Shield's Veteran and Elite difficulties imo.

+ Atmosphere is just like the old Rainbow 6 games (e.g. rooftop biolab insertion feels exactly like the Raven Shield Penthouse insertion zone).

+ You die in 1 hit most of the time unless you equip heavy armor, in which case you can take 2~5 hits. This is exactly the same as in each of the old Rainbow 6 games. It depends on where you were hit and the caliber of the gun that the guy who shot you has. HOWEVER, unlike in the old Rainbow 6 games, when you wear Heavy armor you are not allowed to sprint (default: LCtrl) anymore. imo that's completely fine.

+ Hit detection on narrow edges (like shooting through doorways at tight angles) are exactly the same as in Raven Shield -- presumably because they're built with the same engine.

- When you die, you don't get any feedback about your stats or whatever (e.g. accuracy, how many kills you got, et cetera).

- There's no indication of how many enemies in total you're up against. Because of this, you can easily get bored running circles around the map searching for the last guy.

+ The game can only be done slowly, so it's just like Rainbow 6. imo, it's even slower than that, though -- I'll explain why I think this later on down this list.

+ The relationship between accuracy and movement feels exactly the same as in the old Rainbow 6 games (but it goes out the window when you scope in or use ironsights, which did technically exist in the old Rainbow 6 games because you could still zoom a little even without a scope anyway -- it just didn't look like that once they introduced first person weapon models in Raven Shield).

- It lacks certain functionality that people consider basic" or "essential" nowadays (e.g. being able to change options while in the middle of a mission) but weren't exactly taken for granted back in the old Rainbow 6 days. Most â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥s on the internet seem to judge a book by its cover
recommended: and so they look at this lack of "basic" functionality in the menus and just drop the game completely and tell everyone it â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing sucks. In my opinion
hoursPlayed: people who do this can go suck a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.\n\n- TotalBiscuit complained about how there are only 3 graphical settings in his review videos

votesHelpful: except the pace is slower (tbh Rainbow 6 and Rogue Spear both were very fast paced in terms of movement and it wasn't until Raven Shield that they slowed it down
votesTotal: which I loved personally... but this game slows it down even more while still letting you run and sprint through clear areas at the old Rainbow 6 and Rogue Spear running speeds

reviewText:
Horribly dissapointing! If you want some realistic or tactical shooters than pick up one of the followign instead: Insurgency, ARMA3, Rising Storm or DAYZ. reviewText:
This game was not worth 1.50.
I should have never sold my cards to buy this game, it's not even a real tactical shooter. It's a slow paced shooter with several tactical elements, like.... walking very slowly.

There is no fluid door opening, and if you open a door, you are more than likely going to die unless you place yourself at a wall. The options for this game are absolutely horrid. At max sensitivity, I still feel incredibly sluggish, making me want to throw up. Literally.

The AI are as dumb as bricks, but they have an insanely fast reaction time ( wut? ).
Occasionally, you'll be able to kill 20 enemies with ease, due to how stupid they are, but sometimes, you will be insta-killed by the game by an enemy who will use only about 0.2 seconds to shoot you. This is coming from someone who has fast reflexes and good aim. Not to mention, when you do actually get shot at, you will shot in the head. This happens 90% of the time and it makes the medium and heavy armor types very useless.

The equipment options in the game are very basic, you get a frag grenade, a flash grenade, and a breach charge. The flashbang usually doesn't work, as terrorists seem to be completely normal ( By shooting me in the head ).
They don't retreat from frag grenades, oddly enough... But the grenade physics make them feel like rubber balls.
Breach charges are generally useless, as the AI will either open the door on you as soon as you put the charge there, or... There won't be anyone in the room.

The mission variety in the game is pretty awful. There's only about 5 different missions, and this game was released several months ago.

The community is either non-existant, or extremely stupid TKing trolls. You get 1 of the 2.

The friendly AI is extremely stupid, worse than the enemy. You get terrible command options over them, and you are unable to seperate them and tactically manage them. You can tell them to follow you or watch a certain area, which barely works. You can't have 2 guys watch the door and have your sniper on the roof, because there is no way to tell them to get into a specific location.

The weapons and damage in this game are REALLY weird. For a tactical game, it's weird how you don't even have to aim to accurately hit a target. Aiming is useless in CQC, you have a better chance to charge and strafe. And when you do aim, you can literally strafe left and right ( ADAD Spam ) and dodge most bullets. Except from the guy who instantly headshots you.
Don't put weapons into full auto, just put your weapon in single shot and click as fast as you can. You can get much better accuracy and less recoil, while killing targets in 1-3 hits.

The enemy AI in this game is really immersion breaking. ( If you wanted that kind of thing ).
They seem to charge at you DIRECTLY ( Not heading towards cover ) or, they run away from you and do a 180 and headshot you, then retreat again into a random corner.
The AI doesn't patrol around an area, engage in conversation with other AI, or do anything.
Their only goal is to wait for you and to kill you. Being stealthy in this game has no benefit, most of them will somehow know where you are anyways, and then instantly headshot you. Surviving a bullet is rare, especially since armor isn't protective.


(RECAP)

There isn't a real story in the game, so that's a negative.

No planning mode. A minus on the 'tactical' side of things.

No advanced room clearing tactics. Just open and peek in until everyone is dead.

Extreme lack of AI commands.

Dead Community, about 40 players at MOST. I'm pretty sure Star Wars: Battlefront 2 has 180 players at most. Which is extremely sad.

Extremely sluggish controls, including mouse sensitvity.

Extremely barebones options menu. Extremely barebones menu in general.

Very slow-paced, but not tactical.

Not fun, or engaging. Instead of being intense, this game is more than likely going to make you rage.

Buggy. ( After several months )

Huge lack of content.

Terribad AI.

Un-immersive. No cool features either, like a tactical map or an overhead picture you can draw on or a planning mode.

Lack of customization. Pick your guns, what armor, what you want on your patch, and what equipment. That's it.

Completely random crashing and connectivity issues.

1/10    -At least they tried-
Actually, I don't even know if they tried, they seemed quick to place the game on Xbox Arcade.

I recommend that you buy Rainbow Six: Raven Shield instead of this garbage.
It's a much older game, but it's also much more fun.
Especially with friends, where as this game makes everyone just get angry at each other until everyone leaves.

reviewText:
This game has some potential but suffers severly from a few issues, namely:

a) AI that is, at the same time, beyond stupid and annoyingly precise in it's shooting. Bad guys go from not seeing you at all to sniping you with a slingshot from across the map. Oh, and they take out the entire rest of your idiot squadmates before you can even switch characters. Which leads me to...

b) No squadmate commands. Horridly annoying with the AI as completely mentally handicapped as it is in this game. This means you can't even use your blind/deaf/can't hit â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ squadmates at scout fodder. It also makes any kind of tactics like what you might be used to in Raven Shield completely impossible.

c) Horrid interface design. It's completely unintuitive and doesn't flow.

d) Nagging Issues: Here's one -every single door on every map starts open". Minor in the grand scheme of things but annoying combined with a and b above when a hostile snipes you through 5 bulkheads or doors that would otherwise be closed. It's worth mentioning because it demonstrates the complete lack of polish on this game
date:
and this isn't the only example I could have picked.

e) There are other numerous issues that individually aren't huge but combined make for a frustrating experience.

f) The developer doesn't seem interested in addressing player concerns. For the longest time I remember every complaint was responded with "Due to the hardcore nature of the game...". It was used as an excuse for exceptional game-breaking bugs (like the aforementioned horrible AI).

The map design
hoursPlayed: I thought was decent even if it feels a bit sparse or dated. A few of them are good enough I'd love to play them in Raven Shield. Frankly though this game just isn't worth it
voteText: and the developer doesn't seem interested in fixing it. This game is simply incomplete. I haven't dumped a lot of time into it and I have zero desire to bother again. While it has the potential to be pretty awesome at the moment it offers nothing you can't get elseware."

reviewText: I've played a lot of games in my life, yet never have I played a game where one can put a breach charge on a door, stand behind a wall about ten feet away from the door, and get killed instantly by a pebble of debris from the door's explosion. This game also boasts pistol ammunition that can kill a man from ten miles away and AI that walk into walls, shoot mentioned walls and then have their bullets ricochet from the walls into you for one reason or another. This game is so awful that it can't help but be hilarious, and I'm glad I payed the $0.99 to get it while it was on sale. Would I buy this game at full price? No, but it was worth what I payed for it. Long story short: buy this game if and only if it's on sale; any price higher and I wouldn't recommend it.

reviewText:
Takedown is a mess, but I've enjoyed the game nevertheless.
It's glitchy as hell, and the netcode is unreliable, but when I have played with friends online I've had fun.
It's a barebones experience. Do not expect a planning stage, or any team AI control beyond hold/follow commands and basic rules of engagement modification. The campaign is also short, and somewhat disjointed.

The fact of the matter is that this game was obviously in an Early Access state upon release (The install directory of the game even lists it as Takedown Red Sabre Early Access")
date: and wasn't listed as such in the store. That was enough to deal a severe blow to what could have been a pretty decent little tactical shooter.\nAt this point
recommended: while I hope the developers will continue fixing and improving on their design
hoursPlayed: there's little incentive for 505 Games
voteText: the publisher

votesTotal: but as much as part of me wants to dismiss it wholesale

column17: and there is no way to recover health.\nThe AI opponents have moments of startling cleverness
column18:
though most of the times they drop you will be due to not cursoring over them fast enough to evade their sometimes exceptionally quick and accurate weapons fire.
There's a tenseness to the action that would be lost if the damage model and AI were more forgiving.

The map designs are open and interesting
column19: each one providing you with two potential "insertion points" which determine where you start. Some of the design is actually fairly visually attractive
column20: though strange things like reflections that don't actually reflect the environment in a coherent way can slightly mar the experience. (Particularly in the "HQ" level.)\nDespite there being numerous doors on most maps that are purely decorative and don't open
column21: there's a refreshing amount of freedom to how you approach each mission. The nonlinearity also scratches an itch I haven't had many first-person games reach recently. This isn't always player-friendly design in the sense of providing easy and obvious ways to progress
column22: but I'm not sure this is a situation where one can have their cake and eat it too.\n\nHUD is rather minimal

reviewText:
I was a huge fan of tactical shooters such as rainbow six or ghost recon. and I have to say this game fall short in many ways

the team controls for a start are pretty rubish, meaning that you cannot control 1 unit at a time causing any form of strategy to be difficult.

also there is no move here function which I find crucial to any tactical shooter

enemies die in just 1 hit no matter where you hit them and their AI ranges from complete idiot to constantly aware supersoldier for no apparent reason

this game could probably be made better either through modding or by adding updates but alas both are unlikely to happen any time soon

reviewText: Horrible, unfinished, sloppy piece of crap game that obviously needs it's A.I fixed. The levels are good and missions are decent enough, but if you so much as open a door to outside Gary who graduated top of his class in A.I Academy will snap his pistol up and shoot you from the hip 2.7 miles away the moment your head breaks the plane of that door. That being said if you have 2-3 friends who are masochists this game is a blast trying to clear out missions together as the broken A.I makes this game challenging for an entirely different set of reasons the developer intended for.\n\nAccidently made a lobby in multiplayer and someone was actually on and joined in. I'm half certain it was the actual creator of the game cause I don't know anyone that hates themselves enough to play this game singleplayer.

reviewText:
I'll try to be fair on this one:

Pro :
***Okay-to-good graphics
***Okay sound design
***So ridiculous it's almost fun

Con:
***Not a tactical shooter
***NOT the spiritual successor for Rainbow Six games. Rainbow Six franchise is great, this game IS NOT
***Terrible AI (50% aimbot killers, 50% dumb as a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing brick)
***Only 6 maps. Enough said.
***The protagonist doesn't feel like a Spec OPS dude. Deadly 2.5meters-fall damages, seizure-ish recoil, slow as hell.         Â Â Â Â Â seems like the force ran out of men to dispatch and sent an old lady instead.
***The available equipement is so diverse and rich it looks like a 12 years old's paintball arsenal

I think it's enough and that you understand what I mean.

TL;DR: This game will give you cancer. And Ebola. And you'll puke a little if you play it.

My rating : [Standard mag capacity of a 92FS] / 100

Takedown: Red Sabre is.. painful.

It fails as a tactical shooter. Planning is non-existent, there's no map in the briefing and no ingame map. There are no squad commands past wait" and "follow". Your AI companions are basically extra lives for when you inevitably die. Flashbangs either don't work
date: or they blind you through a wall. There are no smoke grenades

reviewText: Okay, I've put in a fair amount of time to this game, -90% off? FPS Game that is tactical? Sure! Bought 7 copies for 5 dollars, and got it to work as soon as i put it in, okay. The loadout is personally my favorite aspect of this game, you get to make your own loadout, to fit your personal standards, cool. But the game, is, TERRIBLE, first off, when you play the training, its basic, you already know how to fit this game, the controls are standard, but serve no purpose. When you play your first mission, you will know what I'm talking about. The AI is too smart, smarter than your highly trained SWAT team you have following you like mindless zombies. When they see a bad-guy, they say Tango Spotted, so I tell them to shoot it, they just look at it though. The enemy AI always knows where you are. Your only intel is what the game gives you. You spend more time getting killed by super buffed pirates than you do killing pirates that aren't trained. If you're going stealthy, you'd expect that they wouldn't know where you are. But really, all they do is aim at you, until you come into the direct line of sight, then they start running after you. Glass is bad for you, because you can't entirely see through it, but the enemy can, and shoot at you, killing you on the first hit. There are around 2-3 people that are programmed to look in a certain direction, and not staring at you the entire time. Your team is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, you cannot tell a single person what to do. You have a sniper, an assault, and a breach, you are supposed to be the recon, but what if you don't like that class? Your team will stare at a bad guy, but not fire. They do not know where a single person is, until the person shoots them in the head, with their 99.99% accuracy, while yours and your teammates accuracy is 80%. Your team is clunky, ending up alerting the enemy before you can scope out the map, because you cannot make them wear different armor, or armor fit for what you want to do. The mission always wants you to go steath, when the mission objectives call for action. Your team always has silencers, when you don't even need them. Now I'm getting started on multiplayer. Half the time, you're on the team with a prick, who only wants you to hate the game you payed for, it's not even free, so they kill you with their insta-kill guns, wearing huge-â™¥â™¥â™¥ armor, so they kill the entire team before the game even really starts, then they kill themselves, because they're bored. Other than that the maps are too big for 6 on 6 team deathmatches. If you could have 12 people on each team, then it would be fair, and the match would be 90% more interesting, but it's full of boring experience. I was lucky to buy the game for less than a dollar, you, are not. If you really want this game, just message me and I'll send you a copy. But be warned, until the makers seriously patch this game. IT'S NOT WORTH IT. 2/10

reviewText:
Takedown: Red Sabre is a return to the original gameplay of Rainbow 6; complex environments with the classic counterterrorist missions. The base mechanics of the game (assuming you can play it; I had to disable my joystick to prevent input interference that spun me in a continous 360 to the left) are promising: as a technology demonstrator this should secure future funding. Unfortunately the niche 'tactical shooter-simulation' market continues to play the old, proven games for very good reasons: Namely that they have content and they work reliably. This is not something that Takedown: Red Sabre (TRS) can boast. I have 0.7hrs of gameplay because the game simply refuses to start despite recent patches and I had to solve the competing inputs issue before I could review the base mechanics of the game. Graphics are as you seen on the screenshots, entirely satisfactory.

TRS is missing a great deal: Storied, biographed team-mates, working multiplayer, mission briefings, a campaign, a planning phase, all of the things that made Rainbow 6 a remarkable series of games prior to its franchisement into â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ pap for consumption by mentally damaged children. There's no reason these features cannot be applied to TRS, save for the developer's sham development process.

Make no mistake: TRS is at present one of the work in progress" or "fund us as we go" games made possible by Steam's update distribution function. Such a development model was previously impossible for technical reasons
date: but for marketing reasons I think TRS will prove that it should not be adopted now that the technical hurdles have been overcome.\n\nMost of the early negative comments regarding TRS were from "railshooter" players who have never asked more of their games than a scripted cinematic experience with no replayability and largely
recommended: no challenge or critical thought required. These were unfounded negative comments. Subsequent commentary has focused on the incomplete and outright flawed nature of the game
hoursPlayed: and what Serellan LLC has done is take a dormant market hungry for new content and alienated it completely in the span of two months. Bravo zulu; you have now created the textbook negative example.\n\nDo not bother with TRS until vast
voteText: sweeping changes are made.\n15-10-2013."

reviewText:
Where do I start?  Off the bat, lets get this bit out of the way, yes this game is awful, in almost every way you can think of, and a few you haven't yet.  But despite that, on occasion when they let their guard down I manage to convince a few friends to shuffle (that's what you do in this game, you        shuffle, noisily) behind me in a few (you can only manage a few before you'd prefer to remove your own eyes rather than keep playing) games of the various coop missions.

Yet somewhere in there, and I can't quite put my finger on it, there's something I'm quite fond of in the game.

I often think, that if you gave a turnip enough time, and a few beginners guide to Pascal lessons, this is exactly what they'd come up with.  You'll never understand it, but its amusing just the same.



There is potential here, I believe there is  a need for such a game rite now, and you do get a sense of the innovative and exciting ideas that are fueling this game, they just don't come through yet.

Do you buy it?  Of course.  I'd really like to see It grow,   Its not where it wants to be yet, but I'm sure Christian Allen and the team at Serellan will take it there.  Check out their site, they are indie game development team that really value their community and are listening.  This is why I'm continuing to support it.

reviewText:
It's a dreary afternoon in Canberra, Australia, and I have nothing to play. I have an idle $2 remaining in my Steam wallet, and on impulse, I buy a game I notice is 90% off; the game is Takedown : Red Sabre.
I download the game and finally press the play button. I navigate the menus, and select the Biolab mission from the Singleplayer menu. I wait intently through the loading screen, feeling excitement in my fingertips.
I'm in game! My character is hefting an assault rifle and a pistol, both deadly weapons in capable hands. I walk down the stairs, and no enemies are in sight. Despite this, my character falls on the ground, dead. In a room that is empty, except for myself.
3 minutes in Takedown : Red Sabre.
In all seriuousness, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ game, don't buy it.

reviewText:
I am a extremely big fan of the older tactical games. Especially Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield. I loved that game. And still do. So when I found out that one of the creators was working on a new game I went nuts. I told all my friends to buy it, and most actually did because we had such fond memories of the older tactical shooter games that aren't really being made anymore.

Needless to say, my friends now hate me. This game lacks in every front. Graphically, map-wise (everything is very empty), the gameplay itself isn't good at all. Technically it's a mess. The AI is atrocious.

Please do not purchase this game.

reviewText: Many people were thrilled when they heard they'd be getting a tactical shooter again in this day and age of action shooters like COD. The premise of tactical team-based combat ala SWAT and Rainbow Six is mouthwatering to any veteran team-player. With one of the key designers of the classic Rainbow Six games behind the helm it almost seemed too good to be true and unfortunately, it kind of is. First off i'll state the games has MUCH promise and the prospect of user generated content is fantastic, but the problem with Takedown is it lacks character and style its predecessors had. It feels very generic and lifeless plus the addition of serious network hiccups and server browser issues dosent help. If you played Realistic Shooters" like Operation Flashpoint Dragon Rising
recommended: or ANY of the 3 Rainbow Six games
hoursPlayed: you'll learn this game pales in comparison to those. It has a budget price but for that same price you can buy one of the games i just mentioned and they would be more worth the buck. All in all
voteText: the initial feeling for this game is disappointment
helpfulPercent: but only time will tell if the devs can somehow redeem these critical mistakes."

reviewText: Got this game for free from the forums. Someone bought a four pack for some friends but they all denied the gift. Said I might as well add it to my collection of games I would personally never play. But then I wanted to get first hand on what everyone hated about it, So I hopped on bourd the shi* train to shi*ville and had a very short ride there. Right when I opened the game it I was in an avalanch of loud music and badly made intro sequencing that for the life of me could not skip, to get to the poorly made homescreen. I then went first to the training sequences to get a feel of the game. Trust me when I say this. There was no Feel" Besides me bashing my head on the keyboard as I had to listen to the voice instructor and be frozen still for a good 20 minuets as he explained how to pis* in a can. I then got board and just got online. Seeing that only one server was active I joined and from my surprise. They were all 10 year old kids talking about eachothers mothers
date: I then tried playing the game. As I entered a room to get demolished by a guy facing the other direction as he shot at the wall. I then left the game. Deleted my :System32: File and said screw it to the world of videogames. Since then I have gotten married wrote a novel and even finished lawschool and now I am going to be a sucessful man in the name of the law. Overall long review short this game is the best thing thats ever happened to me and the time I played of it will be the best memories of my gaming career I once withheld. Thanks 505 Games!"

reviewText:
This was supposed to be the great hero that would bring back hardcore tactical co-op first person shooting to the old farts like myself, who have been waiting for a successor to games like Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six 3 and SWAT 4. It held great promise and the developer spoke such sweet words, pouring honey on the ears of the people like me. Then it was released...

At first it seemed like a game with some launch hick-ups and bugs. The basis was there for T:RS to take this not-so-well sought after throne, but every update was just making more and more of a mess. Then, not very long after release, they started to sell it for 1â‚¬ and gave all owners an extra copy to give away to unsuspecting enemies friends... which is kind of a clear sign that they threw in the towel and gave up on it.

As said; the basic foundation is there; a hardcore, slow paced, co-op, tactical game... if you can get into it. It's hard enough to get a group to successfully join a server, but then you can't make that server private. The AI seems okay at first, but is actually bugged out like crap in a thunderstorm. The game freezes, the game rolls over like a dog without anyone commanding, the game just doesn't do what it's suppose to and does everything it's not suppose to. The only thing that worked from the get go; the in-game text-to-speech chat, they had removed in an update. First the maps were all too big, so you were running around searching for the last terrorist... then they made them smaller, but made them minimal.

Nothing has gone right with Takedown: Red Sabre, and my kind (the hardcore co-op FPS:ers) had to look elsewhere. Fortunately we found Insurgency, which is a bloody good game; get that one instead!
The only thing T:RS managed to do was to have our gaming group make sarcastic jokes about ...it's in the hardcore nature of the game." and "...this game is epic!" which were compliments once upon a time
date: but after the release and subsequent downfall of T:RS have now become the worst insults we can say about a game.\nIt's all just really sad..."
hoursPlayed: false

reviewText:
As many reviewers have stated, the game is buggy and needs a lot of work. However, the game is playable(barely) IF you can work past those glitches.

So, what is there beyond a buggy game? Visually the game is beautiful! Impressive textures, and lighting, and while the animation leaves much to be desired, everything else is rather good.

The game labels it's self as a return to old school tactical shooters, which couldn't be farther from the truth. Yes, it's tactical in the sense that one hit will kill you, and you should be extra wary of your surroundings if you want to live, but does not even come close to the tactical FPS that it claims to be a return to.

Overall, it's not an overly terrible game, and certainly has potential and is a pleasant bit of eyecandy, but just doesn't seem ready for release. By all means, if you see this on special for a really low price, pick it up! Otherwise stick to classic Rainbow Six game.

Unfortunately at it's current price, and current state, I can't recommend it.

4/10

reviewText: Do not buy this game. This is one of those games that metacritic will give a 32 for a good reason. The people who developed Take Down: Red Sabre probably had a good idea in mind, but executed it horribly. Take Down tries to bring realistic shooters to the modern day scene full of CoD and BF, but falls flat in a wide variety of aspects. First off, the gunplay is some of the worst I have had in a while. It consists of a poorly model weapon of choice with what seems like no recoil, but the spread on these guns is absolutely ridiculous after the first round. Second off, the AI is down right â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, including your enemies and squad mates. It seems that there is only two different poles to this AI, they will either be A) Seal Team Six grade soldiers or B) third graders that had their heads smashed in with hammers. The enemies also have something similar happening, they will either kill you instantly with one shot, no chance to kill them, or miss every single god damn round in thier mag. The AI enemies also have unfair" tactics sometimes
date: most often involving them clipping through the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing wall and blasting you and the remaining members of your squad striaght out of the game. The map design is also rather subpar in comparison to most games these days
recommended: consisting of almost exclusively CQC oriented environments
hoursPlayed: and mass enemy spawning. The worst part about all of this is that this is a game coming out in 2013 and very well could've been the spiritual successor to Tom Clancy's: Rainbow Six series

reviewText:
I think I remember seeing this on kickstarter or something. Trying to revive the tactical shooter genre, comparing Takedown to classics like Rainbow Six and SWAT.
This game doesn't even come close, though. I am so badly disappointed, I wish steam offered refunds, just so I could get my dollar back. It was on sale 80% off, $0.99, so I figured why not.

The devs won't shut up about how tactical you have to be. How thoroughly you need to plan, how prepared you need to be, blah blah blah.
The only tactics" in this game seem to be:
Peek around corners and shoot bad guys before they shoot you.
Try to be sneaky and quiet.
Fail at being sneaky and quiet because the bad guys apparently have the best hearing in the world
date: no matter how silent you think you're being.\n\nSWAT 4 was amazing. It came out in 2005
recommended: and it has more features and better gameplay than this pile of disappointment.\nIt's pretty sad when a decade-old game is superior in every way."

reviewText:
There are times when your first impression gives you a false perspective on a game, then you go back and play it and realize that the game is not that bad. My version of that is EVE Online. There are also games which you, the player, fail to see why people hate the game so much. For me, Orion: Dino Horde is a great example. Takedown: Red Sabre is neither of those examples. and wasn't worth the 99 cents I paid this past Summer Sale.

From what I assume, this game is trying to be a cross between Counter-Strike and Rainbow Six, but fails at both. The weapons don't feel anywhere near as powerful and fun to use as Counter-Strike and the teammate AI is so bad that it feels more like a series of cheap deaths rather than a tactical experience.  I've had two of my squadmates in single player killed by a guy who seemingly appeared out of nowhere behind me and there was no indication that there was someone behind me. No voice clips, no gunfire from my AI teammates who were just standing around scratching their asses rather than checking in the directions that I couldn't face, nothing. The enemy AI is utterly cheap and the teammate AI rarely does anything to help you and more likely than not follows you around like a lost child looking for its parents.

The online community is dead and for good reason. The control is extremely sluggish and I don't feel like can be stealthy and tactical when I can only walk from room to room rather than running from cover to cover. As stated before, the guns feel weak and the whole pace of the game is extremely off. I initally wanted to play the game long enough to get the trading cards and sell them to make a little return on investment but the game is so bad that I can't even play the game for that long. Avoid at all costs, not worth 99 cents in a sale and the current asking price of 4.99 is almost criminal.

reviewText:
UPDATE 20.12.2014:
I previously recommended this game because I thought it had some potential. I figured if more people strarted playing maybe the developers would try to fix it. I wanted to give this game a chance. Unfortunately it seems like the devs abandoned it. I do not reccomend buying it because you would be buying a broken game that will never be fixed.


MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:
After seeing all the negative reviews I decided to weigh in my own opinion.
Sure, the game is still a bit rough around the edges, but it's fun to play on co-op.
It has great potential and the developers are still working on updates and new content.
If you are a tactical shooter fan you should support the developers instead of hating
on the game and just saying SWAT 4/Rainbow Six 3 are better". Of course these are great
games
date: but they have been around for 9 and 11 years respectively. Are you going to just\nkeep playing them for the next decade and discard everything else
recommended:
because it's not as good?
Or would you rather try and support the people that want to bring back the experience?

If 14â‚¬/$15 is too steep just add the game to your wishlist and wait for a sale.
There's no rush and it's easy to snag it for a fraction of the price. You even
get an extra copy so you can gift it to a friend and play together. Better yet
hoursPlayed:
I'm sure all the people who hate the game so much they say "it gave them cancer"
will be more than happy to trade their extra copy or give it to you for free.
Try reaching out to them.

If all disappointed "true tactical shooter fans" tried to give constructive criticism
voteText: \nparticipate in the community and support the developer
helpfulPercent: we might eventually get the real\nRainbow Six and SWAT successor. The potential is there
votesHelpful: it just needs more polish.\n\nTL;DR: This game is underrated. It has the potential
votesTotal: but we need to support the\ndevelopers instead of hating to make it work.\nAlso
votesFunny:
wait for a sale and buy it dirt cheap.
Or trade for it since so many people have extra copies.

PROS:
- the weapons feel good and behave realistically
- the maps are great
- there is a lot of gear/equipment to choose
- the graphics are good but still run decently on older computers

CONS:
- the AI: enemies are unpredictable and teammates are unreliable
- there is no action planning
- you can only give very basic orders to your teammates

PRO TIP: There is a very useful map guide from 505 Games on the Takedown community hub."

Unfortunately it seems like the devs abandoned it. I do not reccomend buying it because you would be buying a broken game that will never be fixed.


MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:
After seeing all the negative reviews I decided to weigh in my own opinion.
Sure, the game is still a bit rough around the edges, but it's fun to play on co-op.
It has great potential and the developers are still working on updates and new content.
If you are a tactical shooter fan you should support the developers instead of hating
on the game and just saying SWAT 4/Rainbow Six 3 are better". Of course these are great
games
date: but they have been around for 9 and 11 years respectively. Are you going to just\nkeep playing them for the next decade and discard everything else
recommended:
because it's not as good?
Or would you rather try and support the people that want to bring back the experience?

If 14â‚¬/$15 is too steep just add the game to your wishlist and wait for a sale.
There's no rush and it's easy to snag it for a fraction of the price. You even
get an extra copy so you can gift it to a friend and play together. Better yet
hoursPlayed:
I'm sure all the people who hate the game so much they say "it gave them cancer"
will be more than happy to trade their extra copy or give it to you for free.
Try reaching out to them.

If all disappointed "true tactical shooter fans" tried to give constructive criticism

CONS:

reviewText: This game reminds me of playing Far Cry 3 on the hardest difficulty: Be spotted and you're as good as dead. While the AI seem to be unable to notice bullets from a far distance, they react quickly enough if they see you and don't always instagib you, for example, if you are peeking around walls. The wall-peek system, while a good concept, is executed in such a way that you end up having to slowly peek around all of the walls, in order to shoot the guy waiting around the corner before he can see you. This game might be good multiplayer, but the single-player experience feels like trying to use a cheese grater to kill a SWAT team. It's possible, but it mostly relies on luck and the enemies messing up.

reviewText: Do not buy this game. This is one of those games that metacritic will give a 32 for a good reason. The people who developed Take Down: Red Sabre probably had a good idea in mind, but executed it horribly. Take Down tries to bring realistic shooters to the modern day scene full of CoD and BF, but falls flat in a wide variety of aspects. First off, the gunplay is some of the worst I have had in a while. It consists of a poorly model weapon of choice with what seems like no recoil, but the spread on these guns is absolutely ridiculous after the first round. Second off, the AI is down right â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, including your enemies and squad mates. It seems that there is only two different poles to this AI, they will either be A) Seal Team Six grade soldiers or B) third graders that had their heads smashed in with hammers. The enemies also have something similar happening, they will either kill you instantly with one shot, no chance to kill them, or miss every single god damn round in thier mag. The AI enemies also have unfair" tactics sometimes
date: most often involving them clipping through the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing wall and blasting you and the remaining members of your squad striaght out of the game. The map design is also rather subpar in comparison to most games these days
recommended: consisting of almost exclusively CQC oriented environments
hoursPlayed: and mass enemy spawning. The worst part about all of this is that this is a game coming out in 2013 and very well could've been the spiritual successor to Tom Clancy's: Rainbow Six series

reviewText:
Think of COD: Modern Warfare [any], in a S.W.A.T. setting, only a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ nightmare.

If they had spent more time on gameplay and gameplay mechanics, it would have turned out a lot better. Lemme list a few things:

1: You always spawn in the same spot. This wouldn't be an issue, except for the following:
1A: The AI knows exactly where you are at any given time. It might give you a second to two to react, is about all the concession you'll get there.
1B: There are a limited number of map navigation choices from your spawn point, without getting shot, due to the above.
2: The movement mechanics are reminiscent of CounterStrike. Only, not in a good way. It's like putting CounterStrike in Tar, and trying to move. Combined with the above, will leave you dead quite often.
3: Grenades are more of a distraction and danger to the player, than the AI, due to the above.

There were several other things that should have either been fixed, or not implemented at all, which slip my mind.
Not something i intend to go back and play again. I'd rather get on S.W.A.T. 4 or CoD [much as i hate it].

reviewText:
There are times when your first impression gives you a false perspective on a game, then you go back and play it and realize that the game is not that bad. My version of that is EVE Online. There are also games which you, the player, fail to see why people hate the game so much. For me, Orion: Dino Horde is a great example. Takedown: Red Sabre is neither of those examples. and wasn't worth the 99 cents I paid this past Summer Sale.

From what I assume, this game is trying to be a cross between Counter-Strike and Rainbow Six, but fails at both. The weapons don't feel anywhere near as powerful and fun to use as Counter-Strike and the teammate AI is so bad that it feels more like a series of cheap deaths rather than a tactical experience.  I've had two of my squadmates in single player killed by a guy who seemingly appeared out of nowhere behind me and there was no indication that there was someone behind me. No voice clips, no gunfire from my AI teammates who were just standing around scratching their asses rather than checking in the directions that I couldn't face, nothing. The enemy AI is utterly cheap and the teammate AI rarely does anything to help you and more likely than not follows you around like a lost child looking for its parents.

The online community is dead and for good reason. The control is extremely sluggish and I don't feel like can be stealthy and tactical when I can only walk from room to room rather than running from cover to cover. As stated before, the guns feel weak and the whole pace of the game is extremely off. I initally wanted to play the game long enough to get the trading cards and sell them to make a little return on investment but the game is so bad that I can't even play the game for that long. Avoid at all costs, not worth 99 cents in a sale and the current asking price of 4.99 is almost criminal.

reviewText:
I bought this game when it was 1 dollar and got so far around 2 hours of playing time on it. That's well worth 1 dollar in my opinion. But 5 dollars? Not so much.

Now, if you are looking at it for the full price, which is 5 dollars, you should take your money elsewhere. This game was kickstarted and I was looking forward to an actual tactical shooter as everyone else was. The team behind this game were a good set of developers who everyone believed could make a really good tactical shooter that could compare to games like SWAT 4 or the old Rainbow Six games.

What you get instead is a game that seems about 80% finished, with solid shooting mechanics but shoddy texture work and poor AI. The AI sometimes hear you through two walls but sometimes don't notice you when you are next to them. Doesn't make any sense. The online community for this game doesn't exist as everyone has jumped ship on this game. So you're stuck with the AI teammates who just get killed constantly.

For a dollar, if you are interested in a tactical shooter that you'll probably play for a couple of hours, go for it. But if you are looking for a tactical shooter for 5 dollars, look elsewhere. You're just wasting your money here.

reviewText:
Rainbow Six with ramped up difficulty and realistic gameplay. The game is so hard that the player is pushed into a position where they have to use their tactical prowess to survive. Guns basically insta-kill and there are pretty much no revives.

The game, in its complete form, is an utter disaster. The maps are way too linear for tactical gameplay. I kept walking down stairs or into a room with a guy, and it would be who shot first rather than what strategy I used. The map design just doesn't help this mess, and that's only the beginning.

Rainbow Six and other tactical shooters are fun because they don't sacrifice gameplay for realism. In Red Sabre, you can't get revived, and you don't respawn. If you die, you lose, and you are taken back to the lobby. In Hotline miami, you die a lot, but you respawn quickly and get as many chances as you want to complete the level. The same thing goes for Super Meat Boy. The truth is, Red Sabre needs a reason to be worth playing. The graphics are bland, the maps are linear and unexciting to say the least, and I don't feel compelled to completely restart the mission each time I fail at it.

The developers clearly wanted a realistic feel, so that the players would be forced to play tactically. They did almost everything wrong with this game, and it isn't even close to being redeemed. The truth is, there are way better games on the market that do what this game does, but better. Honestly, I feel like this game tries to be unique among other shooters, but goes way over the top, and sacrifices any little bit of fun this game could've been capable of.

reviewText:
Having played this after buying it for 79p (around $1/50 rublei) I can honestly say that I do not recommend this game to anyone. Ever. Even if it's free. There are several issues with the game and I am going to post a few:

1. Lag. Everyone gets lag. It's terrible. However funny it is watching your team walk into walls it gets boring after a while.
2. AI. The bots in this game are terrible. Team mates don't help you and enemies instantly kill you while they are facing into a wall.
3. Shooting. You cannot kill anyone. Insane recoil and no weapon damage as well as inability to aim.
4. Snails. You move like a snail.
5. Feel. The menus are horrible. They don't work. You cannot change loadout for some reason. You cannot change settings during a game and they are very limited. The chat is horrible and messages disappear after 3 seconds. I am yet to find voice chat.
6. Players. Barely anyone plays this and those who do hate it. End of.

reviewText: Absolutely awful game. I was sadly a supporter of the kickstarter for this game. From all the kickstarter support, you would have thought that these guys would have made a better game in every sense of the word. Through their marketing online, they made it seem that this game would be like a more realistic Rainbow Six: Vegas, which was one of my favorite shooters of the past decade. When I finally installed the game I could not belive my eyes. The game was truly terrible. Im wondering if all the money they raised for the kickstarter was used on rendering highly processed screenshots to show us. The game looks and plays nothing like what they showed on the kickstarter and is full of bugs and glitches. Dont waste your money or if this game winds up being free, dont waste your time. Total Freakin Disappointment and Disgrace.

reviewText:
I didn't believe everyone's statements about how horrid, broken, and laughably poor this game was.

Some even went as far as to say that for $1.50 US, it was far too high a price for the quality of the game.

Well, some of that may be hyperbole, but the game certainly is fairly poor. It looks like there was a good vision behind it, but the execution of the vision was horrid on nearly every front.

The engine has bugs galore (dropping to 1fps when I pressed F to reload? Sure, why not), the AI alternates between laser accuracy and Mister Magoo mode, your teammates have the intelligence of a warm cucumber, and the weapons all feel largely the same.

Seriously, skip this game. It is as bad as they say, perhaps worse. However, if you're like me and can't resist trying a game to see if it really deserves the flak (as some certainly do not), give it a go.

reviewText:
What the hell.. If you're going to make a Rainbow-Six clone, at least get the AI right.

The enemy seems to know who and where you are at all times, despite being silenced.
There's not a single millisecond of delay, they see something moving they're already firing.
Makes me wonder how they could take over that building in the first place without shooting each others.

If you're creeping up a corner, they already know you're there and are waiting guns drawn.
This is not fun nor would I qualify this as hard"
date: it takes all the tactics away.\n\nI'm used to FPS and my reaction time is usually under 250ms
recommended: add the rotational speed and aiming I'd guess it's around 750ms and yet i'm too slow. By the time I click
hoursPlayed:
i'm already dying.
And note that the NPC shouldn't be aware of my presence while I knew very well where he was (thanks to metagaming)

Even the worst of the Rainbow-Six games is better than this.
The controls are horrible

reviewText:
Backed it on Kickstarter and really wanted it to be good. Sadly, it's not: The old Rainbow 6 game did this better. The UI is unnecessarily clunky, enemy AI is a bit weird and friendly AI is useless.
Visuals are OK and the game has improved a lot with patches, but still can't recommend it unless you get it for cheap.

May be worthwhile in multiplayer, but I've not tried that.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
My experience in this game so far:

Pros:
+ Tries to be like Rainbow Six
+ Looks like an older generation Rainbow Six Game (Nostalgia?)

Cons:
- Looks like an older generation Rainbow Six Game
- Enemy AI isn't really smart, but shoots fast and pretty acurate
- Multiplayer lacks options like password protection, friends only, friendly fire off, kicking in game, banning in game, muting in game

My experience for the multiplayer so far:

I gave a friend of mine a Key, so we could play a bit of the co-op. The first round went well enough - only that I started to hear a russian kid talking to his family. (Probably should have done his dishes, but failed to do so - I really couldn't understand)

The next round, said russian kid starts to shoot us (Teammates) in the head - procedes to talk gibberish. Probably insulted our upbringing, or our parents. Maybe he asked us, if we could do his dishes. I really couldn't understand.

I tried to kick him, or remove him from the game - put to no avail. We restarted the server.

Now more than just that russian kid joined, but some rather heavily mentally ill as well. We started off to a round of teamkill-gallore and I threw the game into a corner.

No fun, no options, no recommendation
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The game is very clunky and I feel like I have to fight the controles every step of the way, it is not smooth what so ever. The game I understand is supposed to be about strategy, tactics and key timing but your default speed in my opinion is a little too slow. I also had a lot of trouble with spawn points and it just seemed like no mater what type of armor you wore you die just as quick. I'm glade I didn't have to pay for this game because it clearly needs a lot of work done and unfortunately because it seemes like they rushed to put the game out I don't think this game is going to recover anytime soon with such bad reviews and poor gameplay. They talked big game but in the end this game just didn't deliver. I give it a 3/10 just because it has the right idea, the pieces were all there but they haven't figured how to put them together just yet.

reviewText:
This game has 2 major faults.

1. Its supposed to be a one shot one hit foe everything, You, the enemeies, equipment, etc, well thats partially true. You can shoot whatever ya want BUT its almost IMPOSSIBLE to KILL anything but yourself. You can die in one hit but anything else? forget about it.
2. Everything is smarter than you. Its supposed to be stealth playable but its like EVERYTHING KNOWS YOURE THERE. You cannot play it stealithly because it wont let you, and thats the kind of game its supposed to be. Everything practically has super sensitive trigger plates and you take one step and it knows youre there.

it was discounted to $1.24 but with these faults its not even worth that. This game can be used as an insult for Christ sakes.
